bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. PITTS:H.R. 869.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under Article I, Section 8 and Article IV, Section 3of the United States Constitution.[[Page H703]][Page H702]

item.title: White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic River Expansion Act of 2013

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Public Lands and Environmental Regulation.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Public Lands and Environmental Regulation.
Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

item.fullName: Rep. Carney, John C., Jr. [D-DE-At Large]

item.name: Wilderness and natural areas, wildlife refuges, wild rivers, habitats

summary.text: White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic River Expansion Act of 2013 - Amends the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate additional segments and tributaries of the White Clay Creek in Delaware and Pennsylvania as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

bill.title: White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic River Expansion Act of 2013

item.title: White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic River Expansion Act of 2013
White Clay Creek Wild and Scenic River Expansion Act of 2013
To designate additional segments and tributaries of White Clay Creek, in the States of Delaware and Pennsylvania, as a component of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Public Lands and Environmental Regulation.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
